# second()

**Instance Method**

Modifies the date interval format style to include the seconds.

## Declaration

```swift
func second() -> Date.IntervalFormatStyle
```

## Return Value

A date interval format style that includes the seconds.

## Discussion

This example shows a combination of date interval format styles that include the hour, minutes, and seconds:

```swift
if let today = Calendar.current.date(byAdding: .day, value: -140, to: Date()),
   let sevenDaysBeforeToday = Calendar.current.date(byAdding: .day, value: -7, to: today) {

    // Create a Range<Date>.
    let weekBefore = sevenDaysBeforeToday..<today

    print(weekBefore.formatted(.interval.minute()))
    print(weekBefore.formatted(.interval.day().minute().hour().second()))
}
// 2/5/2021, 17 – 2/12/2021, 17
// 5, 8:17:19 AM – 12, 8:17:19 AM
```

## Modifying Date Interval Format Styles

- **day()**: Modifies the date interval format style to include the day.
- **hour(_:)**: Modifies the date interval format style to use the specified hour format style.
- **minute()**: Modifies the date interval format style to include the minutes.
- **month(_:)**: Modifies the date interval format style to include the month.
- **weekday(_:)**: Modifies the date interval format style to include the specified weekday style.
- **year()**: Modifies the date interval format style to include the year.

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to include the day.
items.name: day()

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to use the specified hour format style.
items.name: hour(_:)

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to include the minutes.
items.name: minute()

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to include the month.

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to include the specified weekday style.

items.description: Modifies the date interval format style to include the year.
